text: we realized about a year year and a half
ago that we really had a problem coming
the biggest problem is that it's so
inexpensive it's less expensive than a
six-pack of beer it was kind of like
nothing else mattered you know and I
also felt that I was invincible as well
as almost it would be like Superman's
cape I guess - I don't want anyone to
tell my daughter was a drug addict and
my wife and I came home and we sat and
we talked about it and the next day we
went to the funeral I told the world
that she was an addict
her grandfather had terminal cancer and
he had boatloads of oxycontin and
percocet so we don't know when she
started dipping into the bucket but I
mean he always had so much of it we
couldn't tell she was in high school she
was taking percocet you know I guess
that was all over the place she was
taking that they called him perc 30s it
was 30 milligrams of percocet and then
it got to be expensive she moved up
because she couldn't get his high so she
was taking one or two three at a time
that she went to percocet 80 milligrams
and the cost was outrageous there so the
natural next step was to uh you know go
to heroin she was a good person
just just got the best of her this this
drug won and won the battle every day
she was taking a carload of equipment
out of my office and it just got he
really really bad
and then we went to the local
authorities and I talked to them and and
the first person I talked to was it was
like I know let's just you know arrest
her and that's not really wanted to do I
didn't come to have her arrested I
wanted to get her help
the choices are limited especially in
New Hampshire
you know the services aren't available
as they are in other states
there's no treatment facilities well
there's a very few but there's a six to
eight week lead time to get into you
know if you have a bed you can't afford
it and it's very expensive treatment
it's very expensive 28-day program you
know at ten twelve thousand bucks is
just to go for 28 days when you hear
from parents whose children are addicted
and they take you through some of the
stories you know missing teaspoons in a
house and couldn't understand why that
was happening at the time there were a
lot of parents that don't know those
telltale signs
in the state of New Hampshire we have
the highest opiate prescriptions in the
country per capita this is gone from
rich to poor from white to black from
young to old
I got an injury playing hockey and I
went to the emergency room and it was
nothing too serious but I got prescribed
a couple of percocets to take home and
after that I couldn't wait to find more
and I got introduced to people that were
selling oxycontin and astana was Big
Mike my grandfather got cancer and he
lived with us and he had bottles of them
so they were like readily available you
know and I like the way they made me
feel once you realize you know under
control it's hard to figure out how to
live could you don't let roll I played
college hockey I interned at a district
attorney's office I had positive
influences but at the same time you know
no one was telling me it was okay to
feel sad and feel feel mad and how to
deal with that when oxycotin became
prevalent through percocet abuse nobody
knew what it was we all thought it was
just gonna be something like the cocaine
and you have some fun with it and then
you can put it down not that it was
physically addicting so when it became
more expensive you know it wasn't 30 or
40 dollars anymore was 80 dollars for an
oxy cotton 80 but you could buy a bag of
heroin for $10 you know the cost
comparison became so so much different
the average age of our clients is about
23 24 and it's been like that for a
couple years so they're not the addicts
aren't getting older they're getting
younger which means you know the problem
is now widespread into the youth
there needs to be a continuum of care
you know there needs to be from the day
they enter a five to seven day detox
thirty days into a long term sort of
living for six to nine months and then
follow-up care you know counselors if
someone were to get cancer or diabetes
or have a heart problem they would fall
into a continuum of care and their
insurance would cover and they would
have checkups and support groups you
know unfortunately the attic people are
dying but after thirty days you know
they just hope for a miracle and hope
everything is gonna get well
